questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following organisms can cause both typical and atypical pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Legionella pneumonia presents as both typical and atypical pneumonia. Pneumonia is an infection of the lung parenchyma. Pneumonia that develops outside the hospital 
setting is commonly referred to as community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). There are two types of 
community-acquired pneumonia. • Typical Pneumonia • Atypical Pneumonia

questions.question:
Question 2: There is an outbreak of legionella pneumonia in the hospital. Which of the following is least 
likely to have played a role in the transmission of the organism?
questions.explanation:
Home split air-conditioning units do not use water to cool the air, so they are not a risk factor for 
legionella transmission. The following are the risk factors for transmission of legionella: • Contamination of water supplies in large facilities such as hospitals, hotels, apartment buildings • Contaminated water sources such as hot tubs, birthing pools, fountains, whirlpools • Water using machinery- cooling towers, evaporative condensers, humidifiers

questions.question:
Question 3: A 55-year-old smoker presents with high-grade fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, and 
confusion. Gram-staining of the sputum revealed neutrophilia with no organisms. Chest x-ray 
showed bilateral multilobar infiltrates. Lab values are given below. Which pathogenic agent is 
suspected?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by legionella. Clinical features of Legionnaire's disease: • High-grade-fever( >104 F) • Cough with scanty sputum • Extrapulmonary manifestations involve • gastrointestinal- diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting • neurological- most common-confusion, headache, encephalopathy 603 
Sold by @itachibot • Relative bradycardia • Occurrence of illness in an environment in which water supply is at risk of contamination • Failure to respond to beta-lactams and aminoglycoside antibiotics Investigations: • On gram-staining of the sputum, numerous neutrophils with no organisms • Hyponatremia • Elevated liver enzymes

questions.question:
Question 4: Urinary antigen detection test is recommended for diagnosing patients with? 595 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
A urinary antigen detection test is recommended for the diagnosis of Legionella pneumonia. The 
sensitivity (70%) and specificity (99%) of the test are high. The test can detect antigen even after the initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy. Urinary 
antigen detection test can also be used for Streptococcus pneumonia but is not used due to the 
availability of better alternatives. Other investigations for Legionella: • DFA (direct fluorescent antibody)- is highly specific but not sensitive • Culture- Gold standard, BCYE media is used • DNA detection with PCR Treatment: Drugs of choice are azithromycin and respiratory fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, 
moxifloxacin).

questions.question:
Question 5: A middle-aged man presents with fever, cough with scanty sputum, and fatigue. He had a 
throat infection a week ago. His blood investigations and chest X-ray are given below. Which 
is the most likely causative agent for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with chest X-ray and lab values is suggestive of atypical 
pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The blood investigations show decreased 
hemoglobin, elevated LDH, and elevated unconjugated bilirubin suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most 
common cause of pneumonia. Clinical Presentation: • Pulmonary manifestations: • URTI- tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis • Pneumonia( seen in only 10% patients) • Extrapulmonary manifestations: • Cold agglutinin disease( IgM mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia) • Erythema multiforme or Steven Johnson syndrome 604 
Sold by @itachibot • Arthralgia with adenopathy • Guillain Barre Syndrome • Myocarditis • Pericarditis • Encephalitis • Bullous myringitis Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery. Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of 
atypical pneumonia.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not true for patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia?

options.a: Causative organism cannot be cultured routinely
options.b: Diffuse infiltrates in the lung are seen
options.c: Cefotaxime is the drug of choice

questions.explanation:
Cefotaxime is not the drug of choice for the treatment of Mycoplasma pneumonia. Cefotaxime is a 
cell-wall synthesis inhibitor, hence it is not effective on M.pnemoniae as they lack a cell wall. Investigations: • PCR of respiratory secretions • Chest X-ray shows- • Patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery • Diffuse peribronchial and perivascular interstitial infiltrates • Airspace consolidation • Reticulonodular opacification • HRCT shows- areas of ground-glass attenuation • On PPLO agar (Dienes method) shows- fried-egg appearance. The diagnosis is made by serology/PCR. Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. 
Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

questions.question:
Question 7: A chronic alcoholic presents to the OPD with fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, and 
productive cough. On examination, there is bronchial breathing on the right side and a dull 
note on percussion. A chest x-ray is done. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray are suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella 
pneumoniae. Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement. The 
patients present with red-currant jelly sputum. Chest X-ray shows: • Cavitation • Pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus) 605 
Sold by @itachibot • Bulging fissure sign: Classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar 
consolidation causing fissural bulging; or displacement of copious amounts of inflammatory 
exudates within the affected parenchyma. It is seen in any space-occupying process in the lung 
such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and lung tumors.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 3-month-old male child was brought with a history of fever and respiratory distress. 
Suspecting pneumonia, a chest X-ray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely 
causative organism? 597 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most likely causative agent of pneumonia in an infant with X-ray showing pneumatoceles 
(air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma) is Staphylococcus aureus. In newborns and infants, S. aureus is a significant cause of severe respiratory tract infections, 
presenting with dyspnea, fever, and respiratory failure. Community-acquired infections are often 
preceded by viral infections, most commonly influenza. Among adults, nosocomial S. aureus 
pulmonary infections are frequently observed in intubated patients within intensive care units. S. aureus often causes necrotizing pneumonitis that may be associated with complications such as 
pneumothorax and empyema. Pneumatocoele can also be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, E. 
coli, group A streptococci, Klebsiella pneumoniae, etc. However, Staphylococcus aureus is most 
commonly implicated. Other options: Option A: Klebsiella pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. Patients 
present with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum. Classic chest 
X-ray findings include upper lobe consolidation, classically on the right side, cavitation, and 
bulging fissure sign. The following image shows bulging fissure sign: 606 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia. Patients with pneumococcal 
pneumonia present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. On examination, the involved 
lobes are dull to percussion, bronchial breath sounds, and crackles are heard on auscultation. The following image shows right lower lobe consolidation: Option C: Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, 
fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are 
heard. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, 
interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis. The below chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery: 607 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is the best biomarker for lobar pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
The best biomarker for lobar pneumonia is procalcitonin. The most commonly used biomarkers of severe inflammation are C-reactive protein (CRP) and 
procalcitonin (PCT). Levels of these acute phase reactants increase in the presence of bacterial 
pathogens. PCT testing distinguishes between bacterial (mostly lobar pneumonia) and viral 
infection to decide the need for antibacterial therapy or discontinuation of treatment. CRP, fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A are other acute phase reactants.

questions.question: Question 10: All are components of CURB65 except

options.c: Blood urea nitrogen value greater than 7 mmol/L
options.d: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg

questions.explanation:
Among the options, systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg (Option D) is not a component 
of CURB-65. CURB65 includes blood pressure, systolic 90 mmHg or diastolic 60 mmHg. CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of illness in a case community-acquired 
pneumonia. It includes confusion (C), urea >7 mmol/L (U), respiratory rate 30/min (R), blood 
pressure systolic 90 mmHg or diastolic 60 mmHg (B) and an age of 65 years. Pneumonia severity index (PSI) is another index to assess the severity of illness and the risk of 
mortality in the case of pneumonia. It includes 20 variables and depending on the score, patients 
are assigned into one of the 5 classes. Class, I, II, III - at low risk of death and can be treated on an outpatient basis Class IV & V require hospitalization

questions.question:
Question 11: A 71-year-old man presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, productive cough. On 
examination, the respiratory rate was found to be 32/ min, heart rate of 102/ min, and blood 
pressure of 90/60 mmHg. How will you manage this patient?

options.a: Admit to ICU and treat with azithromycin and ceftriaxone
options.b: Admit to the ward and treat with levofloxacin and doxycycline
options.c: Treat him on OP basis with azithromycin and ceftriaxone
options.d: Admit to the ward and treat with azithromycin and levofloxacin

questions.explanation:
608 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia and the patient belongs to a 
CURB-65 score of 3. The patient can be best managed by a combination of azithromycin and 
ceftriaxone in an ICU setting. After culture sensitivity, specific management is done.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient in the ICU is diagnosed with community acquired-MRSA. What is the best line of 
management?
questions.explanation: The Empiric treatment of choice for ICU in patients with suspected CA-MRSA is: • -lactam (e.g., ceftriaxone) + Fluoroquinolone/Azithromycin PLUS • Linezolid / Vancomycin with or without Clindamycin to cover CA-MRSA

questions.question:
Question 13: An epileptic patient presented with fever, breathlessness, and productive cough for 2 days. 
The last episode of seizures occurred a week ago. On examination, PR-102/min, RR-30/min, 
and oral cavity revealed a gingival infection. Bronchial breath sounds were heard on 
auscultation on the right side. What is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia due to aspiration. The drug of 
choice is clindamycin as anaerobes are implicated. Anaerobes play a significant role only when an episode of aspiration has occurred days to weeks 
before presentation for pneumonia. The combination of an unprotected airway (e.g., in patients 
with alcohol or drug overdose or a seizure disorder) and significant gingivitis constitutes the 
major risk factor. Anaerobic pneumonia is often complicated by abscess formation and significant empyemas or 
parapneumonic effusions.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant 
weight loss. He complains of retrosternal chest pain that is worse on inspiration. His chest 
X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 599 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in a case of pneumonia in a HIV positive patient, along with the 
presence of fever, and non-productive cough with radiographic findings of diffuse interstitial 
infiltrates and symmetric perihilar involvement is Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). A 
characteristic feature of PCP is retrosternal chest pain, which worsens on inspiration and is 
described as sharp or burning. It is important to note that even though the incidence of PCP is the highest at CD4+ counts of 
<200/L (80%), it can be seen in patients with higher counts. Other options: Option D: Tuberculosis (TB) should be considered as a possibility in cases of pneumonia in people 
living with HIV. However, the absence of hilar lymph node involvement, non-productive cough, 
and no extrapulmonary (pleural, pericardial, lymphatic) features are not consistent with 
tuberculosis. TB can occur at any stage of HIV infection. In the early stages, pulmonary TB appears typically 
with upper-lobe infiltrates and cavitation. In advanced HIV infection, with CD4+ T-cell count 
below 200/L, TB presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, minimal cavitation, pleural effusion, 609 
Sold by @itachibot and lymphadenopathy. Extrapulmonary TB is fairly common in HIV, with it being documented in 
40-60% of cases. Option A: Staphylococcal pneumonia most commonly presents with a productive cough, and 
radiologically presents with pneumatoceles (cavitations) Option B: Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia also present with fever, dyspnea, and 
productive cough. Imaging usually shows lobar involvement. 610 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: In an immunocompromised patient, which of the following is the drug of choice for 
prophylaxis of pneumocystis jirovecii?
questions.explanation:
Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as cotrimoxazole) is the first-line 
drug for both prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii infections in 
immunocompromised patients. Cotrimoxazole acts by causing a sequential block of folate metabolism. CD4+ T cell counts below 
200 cells/L are an indication to start prophylaxis.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is false regarding patients with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia?

options.a: Glucocorticoids are indicated if Pao2 <70 mmHg
options.b: Recent oropharyngeal candidiasis is an indication for prophylaxis
options.c: Elevation of LDH is a common finding
options.d: Aerosolized pentamidine is used in the treatment

questions.explanation:
Aerosolised pentamidine is not used in the treatment of PCP. It is used in PCP prophylaxis. Diagnosis of PCP: • Histopathological staining of induced sputum examination • Bronchoscopy with BAL (most sensitive) • Elevated LDH Treatment and Prophylaxis: • Drug of choice- trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) • IV pentamidine- treatment of choice for severe disease in the patient unable to tolerate 
TMP-SMX • Glucocorticoids- indicated if PaO2 <70 mmHg or with an A–a gradient >35 mmHg • Other drugs used- dapsone/pyrimethamine + leucovorin, clindamycin/primaquine, and 
atovaquone • Aerosolised pentamidine is an alternative used in PCP prophylaxis. 611 
Sold by @itachibot Prophylaxis is indicated when CD4+ T cell count <200/uL ( CD4 cell %<15), recent 
oropharyngeal candidiasis, and prior PCP infection.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 36-year-old male HIV patient presents to the ED with a cough with bloody sputum. He also 
has night sweats, chills, and difficulty in breathing. A chest X-ray and examination of the 
sputum show the following findings. Which of the following is the drug of choice for his 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray and gram-staining is suggestive 
of Nocardiosis. The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole. Nocardia is a gram-positive and acid-fast bacteria. Nocardia pneumonia has a sub-acute 
presentation with mostly cough with thick sputum and fever. Generally, hemoptysis is 
uncommon. Chest radiography shows nodular infiltrations involving bilateral lung fields. Extrapulmonary manifestations are common, the brain is the most commonly involved organ. It is 
associated with dense bilateral infiltrates with cavitating nodules and subacute brain abscesses. The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole. Severe disease is treated with a combination of 
cotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone, or imipenem. Note: Mnemonic SNAP: Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice for Nocardia. For Actinomyces, Penicillins are the drugs of choice.

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia 
in OPD?
questions.explanation:
Azithromycin is the drug of choice for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in an 
OPD setup. Outpatient management of CAP: 1. For previously healthy patients who have not taken antibiotics within the past 3 months: • A macrolide – Azithromycin, 500 mg orally as a first dose and then 250 mg orally daily for 4 
days, or 500 mg orally daily for 3 days, or • Clarithromycin, 500 mg orally twice a day; or • Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day 2. For patients with such comorbid medical conditions as chronic heart, lung, liver, or kidney 
disease, diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, malignancy, asplenia, immunosuppressant conditions or 
use of immunosuppressive drugs or use of antibiotics within the previous 3 months: • A respiratory fluoroquinolone (moxifloxacin, 400 mg orally daily; gemifloxacin, 320 mg orally 
daily; levofloxacin, 750 mg orally daily) or • A macrolide (as above) plus a beta-lactam (amoxicillin, 1 g orally three times a day; 
amoxicillin-clavulanate, 2 g orally twice a day; cefuroxime, 500 mg orally twice a day). 3. In regions with a high rate (> 25%) of infection with high level (MIC  16 mcg/mL) 
macrolide-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae, consider the use of alternative agents listed in (2) 
for patients with comorbidities. 612 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Vancomycin, Ceftriaxone, and Streptomycin are administered parenterally, and 
hence, not appropriate for outpatient management.

questions.question:
Question 19: 601 
Sold by @itachibot What is the most likely causative organism of ventilator-associated pneumonia among the 
following?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, Acinetobacter species is the most commonly isolated organism in cases 
of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP develops in a mechanically ventilated patient 
>48 hours after endotracheal intubation. The organisms causing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) significantly vary from one 
hospital to another. However, the organisms that frequently cause VAP in hospital settings are 
Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter sp., Stenotrophomonas 
maltophilia, and gram-negative rods (Enterobacter species, K. pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli). Three factors distinguish nosocomial pneumonia from community-acquired pneumonia: • Different infectious agent • Different antibiotic susceptibility patterns, specifically, a higher incidence of drug resistance • Poorer underlying health status of patients putting them at risk for more severe infections Within 48 hours of admission, 75% of seriously ill hospitalized patients have their upper airway 
colonized with organisms from the hospital environment. Impaired cellular and mechanical 
defense mechanisms in the lungs of hospitalized patients raise the risk of infection after aspiration 
has occurred. VAP patients may be infected with Acinetobacter species and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. 
Anaerobic organisms (Bacteroides, anaerobic streptococci, Fusobacterium) may also cause 
pneumonia in the hospitalized patient.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is false regarding patients with parapneumonic effusion?
questions.explanation:
Pleural Fluid Protein >4 gm/dL is not an indication of tube thoracostomy. Parapneumonic effusion is pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia, lung abscess, or 
bronchiectasis. When it worsens, it can result in the collection of frank pus in the pleural space. 
This is known as empyema. Risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, alcoholism, cancer, and poor dental hygiene. Investigations: • Chest X-ray: • Loculations or encystments (complicated parapneumonic effusion) • Intrapleural air-fluid level (bronchopulmonary fistula) • Parenchymal infiltrations (underlying pneumonia) • Ultrasound: Shows echogenic pleural fluid with septations and helps in characterizing the 
effusion 613 
Sold by @itachibot • Pleural fluid analysis: • Exudative neutrophilic effusion • Low pH <7.2, low glucose <60 mg/dL, high LDH >1000 IU/L in complicated 
parapneumonic effusion • CECT: Split pleura sign seen in empyema Treatment: • Antibiotics: Tailored according to the microorganism • Therapeutic thoracocentesis • Tube thoracostomy is indicated if: • Pleural fluid pH <7.2 • Frank pus • Microorganism isolated in Gram stain or culture of pleural fluid 614 
Sold by @itachibot Interstitial Lung Diseases and pneumoconiosis
